ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Right ear high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss (HFSNHL)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Audiometry revealed mild-to-moderate SNHL at 4000-8000 Hz in the right ear, consistent with blast exposure.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Left Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Vestibular evaluation identified left peripheral weakness; successfully treated with canalith repositioning.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Functional hearing deficit (Speech-in-noise difficulty)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Performance Perceptual Test (PPT) showed actual speech recognition in noise was poorer than norms despite normal results on other processing tests.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Subjective tinnitus
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Patient reports constant ringing in the right ear, likely associated with the right-sided hearing loss and blast injury.

ordered_list.rationale_short: To assess hearing sensitivity given complaints of hearing loss and blast exposure.
To assess speech reception thresholds and word recognition abilities.
To assess the acoustic reflex arc and screen for retrocochlear pathology.
To investigate reported dizziness and imbalance.
To assess functional speech-in-noise ability and self-perception of difficulty.
To evaluate temporal processing (gap detection) capabilities.
To assess processing of rapid speech.
To assess binaural separation and interhemispheric transfer.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Results revealed normal hearing in the left ear and a mild-to-moderate high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss in the right ear. Middle ear function was normal bilaterally. Vestibular evaluation identified a left peripheral weakness consistent with BPPV.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Right ear: Normal 250-3000 Hz, mild-to-moderate SNHL 4000-8000 Hz. Left ear: Normal 250-8000 Hz with slight dip at 6000 Hz.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: SRTs agreed with PTA; Word Recognition Scores were 100% bilaterally.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.result_summary: Present at expected levels 500-4000 Hz; no decay observed.

tests.name: Vestibular Evaluation
tests.result_summary: Rotational chair and calorics revealed left peripheral weakness; diagnosed as Left BPPV.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Functional testing highlighted a specific deficit in speech-in-noise performance (PPT) that was poorer than norms, while other central auditory processing skills (temporal resolution, rapid speech, dichotic listening) were intact.

tests.name: Performance Perceptual Test (PPT)
tests.result_summary: Actual binaural speech recognition in noise (13.7 dB SNR) was poorer than norms; PPDIS of 0.7 dB indicated accurate self-assessment.

tests.name: Adaptive Test of Temporal Resolution (ATTR)
tests.result_summary: Gap detection threshold 3.26 ms (within normal limits).

counseling_actions: Explained that right-sided hearing loss and tinnitus are likely due to blast exposure.
Discussed functional testing results showing specific difficulty with speech in noise.
Counseled on the benefits of an FM system to improve signal-to-noise ratio in the classroom.
Recommended auditory training to improve processing skills.
Emphasized the importance of hearing protection to prevent further damage.

escalation.rationale_short: Referral to rule out retrocochlear pathology given asymmetric hearing loss and unilateral tinnitus (MRI was subsequently performed and normal).

follow_up_plan.objective: Re-evaluation of functional performance with FM system and review of subjective outcomes.

expected_outcome: Performance Perceptual Test (PPT): Revealed an SNR advantage of approximately +14 dB when using the FM system.
Self-report questionnaire (Auditory Processing): Reflected self-perceived improvement in auditory memory, confidence, and processing speed.
Quality of Life Questionnaire: 6 of 26 items reflected self-perceived improvements.
Patient reported using the FM system at least 3 hours a day and found it significantly improved his daily quality of life and classroom listening.
Patient decided to retain the FM system at the end of the trial period.
